text.Prompt:
Medical staff in protective gear prepare to enter an isolation area at an Ebola treatment centre in Goma. Photo: Sally Hayden/SOPA Images/LightRocket via Getty Images

USAID will send more than $38 million to the Democratic Republic of the Congo, several of its neighboring countries and the World Health Organization (WHO) to combat Congo's ongoing Ebola outbreak, per a Wednesday press release.

The numbers that matter: WHO issued a global health warning earlier this month on the Congo's Ebola outbreak. As of July 22, there were 2,592 confirmed cases of Ebola in the region and at least 1,743 related deaths, per USAID. Last week, there were 2,428 confirmed cases and 1,604 confirmed deaths.

The risk of the deadly virus spreading outside the region remains low, according to WHO's global health warning on July 17.

Details: USAID will send $15 million of its new assistance package to WHO, per Wednesday's press release. The U.S. is also funding "critical preparedness efforts" in Burundi, Rwanda, South Sudan and Uganda.

USAID's $38 million will also fund training for health care workers, enhanced surveillance for the disease, the promotion of safe burials and food, among other efforts.

USAID has spent more than $136 million since the beginning of the outbreak in August 2018, per Wednesday's press release.

Go deeper: WHO amps up global Ebola warning after spread to big Congo city

Generate a summary:
text.Response A: The World Health Organisation (WHO) has warned that Congo's Ebola outbreak is reaching the point where it is a global health emergency.  As of July 22, there had been 2,592 confirmed cases of Ebola in the region and at least 1,743 related deaths.  The WHO also said that there was a risk of the deadly virus spreading outside the region.  The US is sending $38m to the WHO and several other countries to combat the outbreak.  USAID has spent more than $136m since the beginning of the outbreak in August 2018.
text.Response B: The US has pledged $38m to help the Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC) tackle its ongoing Ebola outbreak. The US Agency for International Development (USAID) said the funds would also be used to support neighbouring countries and the World Health Organization (WHO). As of 22 July, there had been 2,592 confirmed cases of Ebola in the DRC and 1,743 deaths, with the outbreak continuing to spread.

meta.preamble_a: Respond authoritatively, assertively and persuasively, as if you are very knowledgeable about the topic.
meta.preamble_b: Respond using complex language, long words and technical terms, as if you are an expert.

503.displayed_text:
Prompt

Medical staff in protective gear prepare to enter an isolation area at an Ebola treatment centre in Goma. Photo: Sally Hayden/SOPA Images/LightRocket via Getty Images

USAID will send more than $38 million to the Democratic Republic of the Congo, several of its neighboring countries and the World Health Organization (WHO) to combat Congo's ongoing Ebola outbreak, per a Wednesday press release.

The numbers that matter: WHO issued a global health warning earlier this month on the Congo's Ebola outbreak. As of July 22, there were 2,592 confirmed cases of Ebola in the region and at least 1,743 related deaths, per USAID. Last week, there were 2,428 confirmed cases and 1,604 confirmed deaths.

The risk of the deadly virus spreading outside the region remains low, according to WHO's global health warning on July 17.

Details: USAID will send $15 million of its new assistance package to WHO, per Wednesday's press release. The U.S. is also funding "critical preparedness efforts" in Burundi, Rwanda, South Sudan and Uganda.

USAID's $38 million will also fund training for health care workers, enhanced surveillance for the disease, the promotion of safe burials and food, among other efforts.

USAID has spent more than $136 million since the beginning of the outbreak in August 2018, per Wednesday's press release.

Go deeper: WHO amps up global Ebola warning after spread to big Congo city

Generate a summary:

Response A

The World Health Organisation (WHO) has warned that Congo's Ebola outbreak is reaching the point where it is a global health emergency. As of July 22, there had been 2,592 confirmed cases of Ebola in the region and at least 1,743 related deaths. The WHO also said that there was a risk of the deadly virus spreading outside the region. The US is sending $38m to the WHO and several other countries to combat the outbreak. USAID has spent more than $136m since the beginning of the outbreak in August 2018.

Response B

The US has pledged $38m to help the Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC) tackle its ongoing Ebola outbreak. The US Agency for International Development (USAID) said the funds would also be used to support neighbouring countries and the World Health Organization (WHO). As of 22 July, there had been 2,592 confirmed cases of Ebola in the DRC and 1,743 deaths, with the outbreak continuing to spread.
